Scott I'm and you know what what's what's interesting is a lot of people will say well you know the free market will correct is the problem is that really in this online space it's not so much a free market anymore and that's really for a couple of reasons Jim or the first one is
The barriers to entry are enormous now you know that may seem strange I mean the perception that a lot of people have is you know Jim if you and I want to start a search engine will just start one and we can put it up on line and people will find it and uh we'll do great it's just not that simple the barriers to entry

All about Silicon Valley it was all about innovation
They had very small footprint in Washington D. C.
They have gone from that scenario to today being one of the most aggressive lobbying country uh companies are having a lot of former politicians on the payroll or making a lot of campaign contributions and very aggressively working the machinery of government for their benefit
And to the detriment of competitors so yeah I think you're exactly right looking at anti trust laws are key
Because we do not have a free market that will correct this problem um and the question becomes how should the company be split up

But I think anti trust is a big part of this smashing the power in the grip that Google has in dominating so much of the information space

To look for information on the line about anti trust actions against Google
A Google controls that flow of information and and it's important to look at the history here [noise] you know again Google official position is

That they were giving safe and and and fair search results well the Federal Trade commission and the Obama administration looked at it
The European Union looked at this academics at Harvard University and looked at it and all of them said Google is lying they are cooking the books
When it comes to commercial search and local search they are manipulating results there's also a body of research done by whip Richard Striner a Harvard a PHD in psychology former editor in
Chief of Psychology Today magazine he certainly series a peer reviewed studies for the national Academy of sciences looking into something that he calls search engine manipulation of fat and what does research results show is that Google has the capacity
And he has research shows they use that capacity to actually manipulate search results on very important issues including political issues so when you think about an antitrust action taken against Google you're not only going to be fighting the way that

Is the idea of an Internet bill of rights that thinking that Google Facebook YouTube and the rest of the bar or less become the digital town square and therefore everyone should have equal access to it
I think that's a I think that's a great point um and and it's really instructive here to look back at how the Internet
Was organized back in the day and in terms of the regulatory structure there was a law passed in Nineteen Ninety six called the communications decency act see da and in section two thirty of that act
It basically split the Internet into two categories
Category one is the the the company or the entity and this is what Google and Facebook claim is that you are a quote unquote neutral platform and basically argument
Here is that all you really are as a telegraph you as a company or conveying information from point a to point B you're exerting no editorial control your not censoring you're not doing any of that if you are a neutral platform
You have no regulation whatsoever and you have no legal liability whatsoever
The other category of course is if you are a publisher you're exerting editorial control if you're restricting certain voices from being hurt Well Google and Facebook insist that they are neutral platforms
But we also know for a fact and they grudgingly admit this that they do exert editorial control so one of the arguments that people have made Senator Ted Cruz has argued this and others
Is that we should essentially tell Facebook and Google you have to choose if you are going to insist on being a neutral platform you essentially as you just said the caller said
You essentially have to allow all voices to operate equally you cannot exert editorial control if you are going to exert editorial control you are now for all intents and purposes is going to be
Treated in some respects as a media company
Now Google and Facebook that is the last thing in the world that they want but I think it goes to the heart of the issue that the caller raises which is you know you have a certain set of rights particularly if an entity claims to be a neutral platform
And I think this is probably the direction that the solution needs to go in addition to the question of breaking up these companies like a gym you and I were talking about earlier in the show
Absolutely again uh I don't know that that ah anything in our history as ever prepared us for something quite of this nature is this is an intersection
Of the traditional issues that face notions of of concentrations of a power economic power and and other power coupled with the er an incredible powers that go with the twenty first century the digital age I mean this is a a whole host of a of a different a
Different color here I mean for example the steel trust over a century ago was very powerful but I'm not sure it's even analogous to this [noise]
I I think this is a hugely important point and I think you're exactly right because it is a media company that controls concepts it's different I mean imagine if in the United states back in the day
One newspaper controlled Ninety percent of the information that would be a huge concern I think to a lot of people but here's the other part of the problem that that that speaks to what you were saying we haven't been here before is
The the kind of actions that Google is capable of taking in Facebook also to assemble the extent
That the problem is we don't know what we don't know because the algorithm is secretive and because the shifting and the editing and the shifting into information is all hidden process
We don't know what we don't know we don't know what is being a kitten from us we don't know what is being pushed in in front of our faces and that's the nature of
What we're facing so it's it's it's a challenge that you're exactly right we have never faced before but it's ominous and it's important I think everybody would agree
That as citizens we benefit from access to all sorts of information all voices in the information um and that is just not happening in this era of these large corporations that feel like they have a duty and responsibility to censor certain voice
Yeah which is another way to put them none of your damn business they have either the duty or the responsibility a I mean that that's the kind of I mean just a ... a ... if he were alive today would think boy I was born to sue this is the perfect tool for running a a Nazi said
No you're you're you're exactly right um and if you think about all the sort of just ... uh uh novels about a totalitarian has and it was all predicated on one thing Jim essentially the power of the state
